cluster_relations.rel_desc: Individuals benefit from participation in sports.
remarks: Relation introduced to attach skill-learning benefits to individuals.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Lessons from sports participation help individuals handle challenges in their personal lives.
cluster_relations.subject_class_label: Life Skills and Lessons from Sports

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: helping individuals become better equipped to handle challenges
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: EffectType: improved ability to handle challenges

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Lessons from sports participation help individuals handle challenges in their professional lives.
cluster_relations.subject_class_label: Life Skills and Lessons from Sports

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: helping individuals become better equipped to handle challenges
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: EffectType: improved ability to handle work-related challenges

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Sports are said to contribute to the economy.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject (e.g., an activity, experience, or set of lessons) provides positive effects, advantages, or life skills to the target entity or life domain.
args.justification: All three relations describe positive effects originating from sports participation or lessons from it and accruing to a target (individuals or aspects of their lives). They share the same directional semantics: the sports-related subject confers beneficial outcomes to the object.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a contributing factor that positively adds to or supports the state, functioning, or value of the object (e.g., sports contributing to the economy).
args.justification: This relation specifically encodes that sports add to or support the economy; the existing raw relation_name already matches a clear, reusable predicate meaning 'acts as a contributing factor to'.

All four relations encode impacts or outcomes (personal, professional, or economic) resulting from sports or sports-derived lessons. Grouping them under a common 'impact_relation' class captures this shared semantics while allowing different predicates (e.g., 'provides_benefit_to', 'contributes_to').

Each relation describes a causal or quasi-causal influence: sports participation and its lessons cause beneficial changes in individuals and their life domains, and sports cause positive contributions to the economy. This fits a broad causal/impact dimension best.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject (e.g., an activity, experience, or set of lessons) provides positive effects, advantages, or life skills to the target entity or life domain.
executed_decisions.justification: All three relations describe positive effects originating from sports participation or lessons from it and accruing to a target (individuals or aspects of their lives). executed_decisions.justification: This relation specifically encodes that sports add to or support the economy; the existing raw relation_name already matches a clear, reusable predicate meaning 'acts as a contributing factor to'.
